text:
Hey folks :wave:
I’m giving a talk next week on the topic of *product-led content* marketing*** and I wonder if you can give me any feedback on what you think/what’s missing/what’s unclear either here or in private?

***_content marketing pieces where the product is woven into the narrative and actively used to illustrate a point, solve a problem, or help accomplish a goal. The idea is to answer the reader’s initial question and inform them at the same time that your product can help—without breaking the flow or inserting a hard pitch._ 

<https://contentfolks.substack.com/p/product-led-content|The structure of my talk is pretty much the same as this piece> → if you can spare a few minutes to check it out, I’ll be super grateful :fire:

elements.text: I’m giving a talk next week on the topic of

marketing*** and I wonder if you can give me any feedback on what you think/what’s missing/what’s unclear either here or in private?

***

content marketing pieces where the product is woven into the narrative and actively used to illustrate a point, solve a problem, or help accomplish a goal. The idea is to answer the reader’s initial question and inform them at the same time that your product can help—without breaking the flow or inserting a hard pitch.
The structure of my talk is pretty much the same as this piece
→ if you can spare a few minutes to check it out, I’ll be super grateful

text:
I think the write-up is solid! Lots of good examples to illustrate, and the points on why it's hard to do make sense without overwhelming.

I don't think what I'm about to suggest is _missing_ per se, but rather a potential opportunity depending on the audience(s)—the idea of storytelling doesn't explicitly come up. The word story is there a few times, and 'narrative' appears too, but there's no explicit connection to the science behind how people tend to pay more attention to/remember/have emotional reactions to stories.

Part of the mistake content producers make when their rating is 0 or 1 is overriding the principles of good storytelling for the urge to sell sell sell—and since people are sensitive to stories, they can certainly tell when a commercial has interrupted it.

This is another angle for "weaving into the narrative" and a possible rabbit hole to explore if your audience values the whole storytelling idea. I've found it's being taken much more seriously these days and while certainly flirting with buzzwordiness, nonetheless has a lot of psychologically verified weight behind it :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Thank you <@U01AHL8AGBB> for taking the time to do this. It’s funny—I stayed away from explicitly mentioning ‘storytelling’ because I have the feeling people hear the S-word it and imagine… fluffy stuff :smile: I need to think about how to introduce it somehow, because your image of the commercial interrupting the story is really powerful. I’ll put my thinking hat back on tomorrow!
